description: Repeated successful IMAP login for user susan.gregory from rip=192.168.128.170; high login frequency may indicate compromised credentials.
Duplicate login event to mail.log confirming access from susan.gregory on same session ID; log redundancy validates previous alert.
Login by damian.jordan from internal address 192.168.128.195, consistent with ongoing lateral movement or persistence with known credentials.
Same login as previous entry, logged in mail.log, indicates successful reauthentication of damian.jordan.
Third duplicate of the same damian.jordan session from syslog; confirms ongoing login activity for this user.
Repeated login of susan.gregory at 09:58:30 from same IP as earlier, with very high firedtimes (300), suggesting automated or brute-forced access.
Same session ID from previous login duplicated in mail.log entry; supports persistent or scripted access activity.
Mail.info entry confirming continued use of susan.gregory account in identical session; log repetition across locations suggests centralized alerting.
First login of michael.davis from IP 172.17.131.81; notable due to proximity in time to previous attacks and new user activity.
New login session for michael.davis from same IP as previous event but different session ID; potentially part of same attacker workflow.
Successful login via IMAP using valid user credentials, method=PLAIN over TLS
Successful IMAP login by user john.hammond via PLAIN authentication with TLS
Repeated successful IMAP login for john.hammond user, possibly normal session continuation
TLS traffic contained invalid record or malformed data, indicating protocol anomaly or evasion attempt
Invalid TLS handshake messages detected, possible evasion or malformed TLS traffic
Outgoing TLS traffic with invalid handshake messages, potentially evasion or network anomaly
Outgoing TLS traffic with invalid record/traffic detected, suggesting possible evasion attempts
TLS invalid handshake message alert in Snort indicating generic protocol command decode anomaly
TLS invalid record/traffic detected communicating with external IP, potential evasion or malformed TLS
TLS invalid handshake message alert by Snort showing generic protocol decode issue
Suricata detected an invalid TLS record/traffic pattern, which could indicate malformed or suspicious encrypted communication used to bypass security controls.
Suricata flagged a TLS invalid handshake, possibly from a malformed or intentionally crafted handshake, suggesting protocol misuse or scanning activity.
TLS invalid record traffic alert reinforces evidence of malformed communication from previous alert; may be related to probing encrypted services or evasion tactics.
Suricata detected another TLS invalid handshake from an external IP to an internal host, which may indicate reconnaissance or exploitation attempt using encrypted channels.
Dovecot login succeeded using plain authentication method; no unusual context suggesting compromise.
Another successful dovecot login; typical behavior, no signs of brute force or unauthorized access.
Repeated successful login with the same user account; pattern appears routine and lacks signs of lateral movement or misuse.
Connection attempt to SSH service without sending an identification string; behavior typical of port scanning or probing for SSH availability.
Unidentified SSH connection attempt from internal IP, likely reconnaissance to check SSH service responsiveness.
Another instance of SSH scanning pattern from the same internal subnet; suggests broad SSH probing for potential lateral access.

Inbound SSH connection attempt without providing an identification string is indicative of scanning or fingerprinting activity, possibly to detect active SSH servers or fingerprint the SSH service behavior.
Repeated 403 errors during GET requests suggest attempts to access restricted web resources, possibly as part of reconnaissance or vulnerability probing.
SURICATA flagged an invalid SMTP reply, which may indicate an attempt to misuse email protocols for C2 or testing SMTP service behavior as part of enumeration.
Attempt to access a restricted directory on the web server, possibly to identify misconfigured or unprotected resources.
GET request using Nmap Scripting Engine targeting /nmaplowercheck path, a known technique to detect Nmap-aware hosts or test server responses.
POST request using Nmap Scripting Engine to a nonstandard path (/sdk), indicative of automated probing of web application endpoints.
Client IP denied access to /var/www/html/ due to server configuration; indicates possible probing for directories with misconfigured access controls.
Access attempt to a known Nmap-generated path was denied, which confirms automated scan behavior targeting specific filenames.
Use of WPScan scanning for WordPress plugin paths; suggests targeted scanning for vulnerable or outdated plugins.
Multiple HEAD requests targeting various WordPress plugin directories using WPScan; characteristic of automated plugin enumeration.
WPScan used to probe WordPress plugin path '/click-to-chat-for-whatsapp/' indicating plugin enumeration.
Use of WPScan to test existence of '/cloudflare/' plugin suggests plugin enumeration for vulnerabilities.
HEAD request targeting '/cloudflare-flexible-ssl/' with WPScan indicates plugin fingerprinting.
Burst of 10 HEAD requests to different plugin paths with WPScan implies automated enumeration activity.
Probing '/bing-webmaster-tools/' with WPScan to determine plugin presence is typical of scanning phase.
Single HEAD request targeting a known WordPress plugin path using WPScan identified in user-agent header, attempting to enumerate plugin presence.
Multiple 404 HEAD requests from a single IP targeting various WordPress plugin directories using WPScan indicate automated probing for vulnerable components.
Another probe for the presence of a specific plugin ('amp') via WPScan shown by the user-agent and plugin path. Indicative of plugin enumeration.
Bulk plugin enumeration with HEAD requests; plugin names suggest a fingerprinting campaign of WordPress installations using known vulnerable plugins.
More enumeration of WordPress plugin directories using HEAD requests and WPScan in user-agent; pattern and frequency match a scanning campaign.
HEAD request to a known vulnerable WordPress plugin directory using WPScan user-agent indicates reconnaissance or vulnerability scanning.
Access attempt to WordPress attachment ID via WPScan user-agent suggests enumeration or probing of resource existence.
Probing for a misnamed wp-config.php file suggests an attempt to discover misconfigured sensitive files.
Request to attachment ID in WordPress via WPScan suggests enumeration of media or posts.
Authentication success via dovecot could indicate either legitimate user activity or the use of compromised credentials.
404 error from accessing /academics suggests a tool scanning for common directories on the site.
Attempt to access access-log.1 file suggests probing for server log exposure.
Multiple requests to various URLs in rapid succession with 404 responses indicate automated directory brute-forcing.
GET request to '/advancedsearch' endpoint with 404 response may indicate automated probing for hidden or misconfigured pages.
Access attempt to '/accountants' as part of mass-scanning activity; likely enumeration of valid paths.
Multiple sequential 404s for various short or admin-like URLs from same IP indicate automated web reconnaissance or directory brute-force
404 error on request to '/beheer', which is a known admin panel name in Dutch, suggests probing for administrative paths
Probing attempt to access possible web calendar plugin under WordPress admin path; indicates directory enumeration
Request to '/wp-admin/user/webcart' under WordPress structure suggests attacker is enumerating plugin or theme paths
Access to .htpasswd file denied; attacker likely trying to access sensitive authentication files
Request to FrontPage server extension DLL path suggests enumeration or exploit attempt targeting known CMS/plugin vulnerability
Attempt to access a likely nonexistent file or resource under known WordPress TinyMCE path; suggests brute-forcing for files or plugin JS
Numerous requests to variations of paths under /wp-includes/js/tinymce/skins/wordpress/, consistent with enumeration or wordlist scan

The log shows an HTTP GET request for a non-existent file in a typical WordPress plugin path, which is often targeted during automated scanning to enumerate resources or vulnerable plugins/themes. The 404 response indicates probing.
Another 404 request targeting a similar directory in a WordPress installation. The pattern suggests automated scanning for accessible resources or plugin/theme vulnerabilities.
Successful login to IMAP by megan.johnson using PLAIN authentication; observed multiple similar entries in a short timeframe
Repeat of successful authentication by the same user megan.johnson within the same second across different log sources
Third instance of identical login by megan.johnson, suggesting this is part of a synchronized or automated login process
New login instance with updated timestamp by megan.johnson; consistent with repeated, possibly scripted logins
Same login as above, captured in a different log file, again indicating a repeated or systematic access attempt
Third appearance of the same login attempt to dovecot by megan.johnson; highly likely part of a brute-force or persistent access pattern
Login attempt to dovecot mail service from damian.jordan, using plain authentication, indicates successful use of a valid account
Suricata detected HTTP protocol inconsistency where response could not be matched to a request; may indicate probing, evasion, or malformed traffic
Snort-equivalent alert showing the same HTTP anomaly detected by Suricata, reinforcing that this is likely real anomalous traffic
Another user (john.hammond) logged into dovecot using plain authentication, TLS secured, suggesting valid credentials being usedâ€”could be compromised
Invalid TLS handshake message detected, indicating malformed or suspicious TLS negotiation that might be reconnaissance or protocol evasion.
TLS traffic flagged as invalid record/traffic suggests either misconfigured TLS client/server or malformed traffic possibly for evasion or scanning.
Repeated Dovecot IMAP successful logins for user 'susan.gregory', possibly indicating a valid account being used for persistence or unauthorized access.
Failed PAM login from same user and source IP, likely indicating password guessing or brute force attempt on dovecot auth service.
Invalid TLS handshake message with an SNI of 'insight.adsrvr.org', commonly associated with ad-tracking; unusual volume may indicate beaconing or abuse.
Suricata alert on outbound TLS invalid handshake, could indicate non-standard client behavior or scanning using crafted TLS packets.
Traffic flagged with TLS invalid record/traffic to Akamai CDN domain may indicate compatibility or client misbehavior rather than an attack.
Multiple invalid TLS record alerts from internal client to external service suggest potentially broken implementation or scan behavior.
Invalid TLS handshake outbound from client to feed.theplatform.com, consistent with misconfigured or probing TLS client.
Suricata signature matching invalid TLS handshake confirms earlier alerts for same flow and endpoint.
User 'www-data' successfully changed UID to user 'phopkins', indicating possible privilege escalation using valid credentials.
Login session opened by user 'phopkins' from UID 33 (www-data), suggesting lateral movement or credential abuse.
Session opened for user 'phopkins' by UID 0 (root), possibly indicating privilege escalation or persistent access setup.
User 'phopkins' executed 'sudo' as root to run an innocuous 'list' command, may be probing root access capability.
A session was opened for user root by UID 0 via sudo, confirming successful privilege elevation.
Session closed for root; this is likely the termination of a sudo session and not inherently malicious.
User 'phopkins' used sudo to recursively list the /root directory, suggesting probing of sensitive files.
User 'phopkins' accessed /etc/shadow using sudo, a common technique for extracting password hashes.
Session opened for user root by UID 0 indicates another instance of elevated access.
Session closed for root. This is a typical cleanup after sudo command execution, not malicious on its own.
